name: Outstanding Plot Twists Quiz | Movies | 10 Questions

questions.text: In "Vertigo", Jimmy Stewart is led to believe that a particular woman is crazy. She isn't. Instead, she is?
questions.explanation:
An impostor.

	Kim Novak isn't really the wife: she's pretending to be her, however, so that the real wife can be murdered. That card isn't shown until well into the movie. Nicely done by Hitch.

questions.text: In "Witness for the Prosecution", the defendant cheats justice (briefly), but then receives punishment. How?
options: He is killed in an accident
He is found guilty of a different crime
questions.explanation:
His wife kills him.

	The wife engages in complicated machinations only to have the ingrate husband shun her for another woman. So ... bang. Clever idea to have the wife frame the husband (intentionallly badly) instead of trying to exonerate him.

questions.text: In "Charade", Audrey Hepburn is deceived by Walter Matthau into believing that he is?
questions.explanation:
A government official.

	He isn't, of course, he's just a villain in disguise. That's not revealed, however, until the very end of the movie. Entertaining.

questions.text: In "Bullitt", there's a problem with the man that Steve McQueen and his fellow officers are asked to guard. What is it?
questions.correct: He's not who they think he is
options: He's not where they think he is
He's a member of the police
He's already dead when the find him
questions.explanation:
He's not who they think he is.

	"You had us guarding the wrong man, Mr. Chalmers". Good action movie.

questions.text: At the start of "Laura", the title character is mistakenly believed to be a?
questions.explanation:
Victim.

	She's dead, isn't she? Apparently not, but we don't learn that for a while. Classic mystery.

questions.text: In  "Stalag 17", key information is communicated between the prisoner-spy and the Germans by what?
questions.explanation:
Chess Piece.

	With a loop in the overhead light wire indicating that the message was there. Good movie. Nice work by Holden.

questions.text: In "The Sting", Newman helps Redford by having someone pose as a cop in order to try to handle a real cop. Who plays the "real cop"?
questions.explanation:
Charles Durning.

	Shaw is the victim of the "Sting". Gould is "Kid Twist", a part of the con team. Elcar is the fake cop. Great fun.

questions.text: In "Malice", Nicole Kidman schemes to get money via a bogus medical malpractice case. Who is her co-conspirator?
questions.explanation:
Alec Baldwin.

	Scott is a doctor. Gallagher is a lawyer. Pullman is the wronged husband. "I am God". Clever plot turns.

questions.text: Turning to the theatre, "Sleuth" is a wonderfully entertaining piece of work with a variety of twists. Anthony Shaffer wrote the play; what else did he write?
questions.explanation:
Whodunit.

	The other three were by the very talented Peter Shaffer. "Sleuth" was Anthony Shaffer's masterpiece; his other works (including "Murderer" and "Whodunit") never quite reached that high a level. (Yes, there is a movie version: don't bother with it.)

questions.text: Turning to novels, "The Magus" by John Fowles is as wild a ride as you'll ever take in the pages of a book. Which of the following is NOT by Fowles?
questions.explanation:
Mila 18.

	It's an amazing novel. "Collector" is also a fine read; the other two are less compelling. (Yes, there is a movie version: don't bother with it.) "Mila" is by Leon Uris.
